threads.com:
/vm/ is a place to discuss all types of multiplayer games, whether on console, handheld, or PC, co-op or competitive, online or local.

Does this mean discussion of multiplayer games is banned on other video game boards? No! /vm/ is just a separate board specifically focused on multiplayer games where discussions about your favorite games can thrive.

Please familiarize yourself with the rules and remember to use the spoiler function where appropriate!

Please note that, like /v/, "Generals"—long-term, one-after-the-other, recurring threads about a specific game are not permitted on /vm/. Such threads belong on >>>/vg/

last_replies.com:
Multiplayer games includes (but is not limited to) Fighting games, First-person shooters, MMOs, Racing games, Sports games, Board & Card games, Party games, and any other genre of game that requires two or more players. Please post threads about single player games on an appropriate board.

Looking for players? Post a LFP thread. Advertising your game servers is allowed and encouraged! Just don't ask for money or spam the board.

Consider using Hamachi, ZeroTier One, or GameRanger for playing old-school LAN games.

>>771192
I had the same problem with the rat's spin after being used to Oren's invincibility. When you see a bomb on screen, the timing for the explosion is always going to be the same regardless of whether it's yours or some else's. Input delay for skills, if there is any, is also consistent so if you can get the timing down once, you can get it every time.
I've been playing against japs every day since it went free to play and it seems like bombs and skills are both handled locally. The one thing that seems to be a problem at high ping is player positions which is only a problem if you're trying to play shooter. This also means that if you practice your timing against the CPU, it'll be the same when you go into a real match.

threads.name: /bng/ - BallisticNG Saturday races
threads.com:
>What is this game?
BallisticNG is a PC anti-gravity racing game available on Steam for $8, based mostly on Wip3out, with optional mechanics from the newer Wipeout games.
If you like going fast, good tunes, and good fun, this game is for you.

>How do I join?
Get the game (Grab the Outer Reaches DLC for $3 if you want, though not required as we mostly play custom tracks anyway).
Download and install the track pack (instructions in the pastebin).
Launch the game, go to Multiplayer, and join what is most likely the only public Steam lobby online. If we are playing in an IP lobby (piratefag friendly) it will be designated at the end of this post or within the thread.

Everything else you need will be here:
https://pastebin.com/tHrNfZdv
Make sure you get the Trackpack
Newest Trackpack (last updated: 2022/09/22):
https://mega.nz/file/m4gHVJQJ#_ay4DAvFLsQ4hlHzDrsZp_9uGjyyVQucGb4HSSdTA_I
Newest Minipack, get this if you're just updating your track pack:
https://mega.nz/file/el4jFCzT#-0lH7G1ENVLM-9lfUE4a11DAwksbw2xPEvzhDfWd6yo
See pastebin for instructions on how to install or update your pack without causing the game to fail to recognize which tracks you have installed.

>How do I play?
Anon guide will be posted, there's 3 parts covering most basics.
Try to practice airbraking and things for a little bit using the Campaign's practice mode before jumping right in otherwise you'll probably have a hard time.
We can also answer any questions you might have, either here or within the lobby.

>I'm bad and not going to win!
Once you get above the skill floor anyone can win races due to their chaotic nature.
Also we always get newfriends who will match your skill level.

We also have a steam group: https://steamcommunity.com/groups/ballisticnv
This is used just for organizing race sessions, no circlejerking.

threads.com: What was something that was missing from old school MMOs and what is something that is missing from MMOs now?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>771404
>MMOs were never really difficult,
That's the problem. Just click, grind, party up. No thought needed. I got spoiled to early text based MMOs back in the 90's where hand made games had actual difficulty curves where you had to not only understand the basic mechanics but actually put thought into USING them was required.

No ruberbanding enemy levels to let you steamroll everything. No NPC tutorials that last until the third or fourth boss fight. No "you lost so have a free chest" or pay to win crap. Just decent level and mob design that lets the players feel they accomplished something more than checking off a box for finishing a grind. More stuff nerfed by the whiners and the low IQ set and bolstered by people supporting lazy designers.

>Relying on set dressing in an open world game instead of bothering with actual quests
A cop out. No matter how pretty the world is, if you can't come up with decent quests it will feel flat and not satisfying. An open world is also not an excuse to have a railroaded story with no changes in story for character build. Most cut scenes are played for each player and not the group anyway. It's just played for the players at the same time. It wouldn't be hard to at least give options on cut scenes. Not nope- too busy making a pretty hill with a stream on it.

Not even being an open world is a valid excuse these days. We have procedural generation right now that can make entire open worlds that only require a little tweaking here and here. Project Artemis is one of the biggest ones being worked on now as it's trying to generate an entire planet. https://playerunknownproductions.net/projects

We have the tech and experience. We can do better. We should do better and support better if we can find it.

Indeed, but fetch quests/kill the boss quests are not railroaded, you're given a singular goal and its up to you to figure it out. If your method for 'figuring it out' is to look up a guide, thats on you, just like you can beat morrowind in less than 20 minutes if you know where you're going and what you're doing.

You seem to understand this, in the fact that you can't have FMV cutscenes involving your group of players, which is why many quests involving groups tend to have the NPCs roleplay a little bit. You're expecting the game to tell you a story, because you're unwilling to experience the story given to you through your own actions.

Have you tried FFXIV? Seems like exactly what you're looking for. As for me I would rather my quests be a checklist for me to complete for personal goals, such as unlocking new abilities and new gear, rather than a chain of linear boring quests that is modern quest design where NPCs constantly talk down to you while you don't actually achieve anything other than unlocking the next set of cutscenes to watch

last_replies.com:
>>771304
D2 and D3 both have big areas that are essentially open world except that the campaign directs you through them and the dungeons are separate zones. Immortal's world design is similar with portals between the zones disguised as paths, yet they call that open world because Ubi style design leads you back and forth around the map. D3 style bounties, repeating world events... not really open world.

I will confess I have always wanted to explire the whole world map including the long trips between labdmarks, with the potential of getting lost or stranded. I love that from the old MMOs and then Minecraft. But Blizzard have no sense when it comes to persistent multiplayer shared space, and are even worse when it comes to chat. You never see the same people in D3 chat and the clan system that could remedy this is an afterthought. D2's chat is unpoliced, not useful in game, and gives no sense of its scope. It's fine that D2 is like this and I imagine no one wanted it changed for D2R, but it should have inspired a good system for D3. WoW is just as bad, with world semi-merges confusing who is where and the game taking people in and out of each other's worlds as needed for stability or to address isolation. There is probably no hope for D4, but I think it's at least worth a try to convince them that this one aspect of Immortal is worth salvaging and using in the future.

threads.com:
Welcome to /VM/abinogi. Mabinogi is a fun, once popular little old school Korean MMO from 2004 based around Celtic mythology with many different features. Your character can age, rebirth, eat food and gain weight, play and custom make music, and so much more. You can be anything and do anything all at once with no downsides. From non combat related skills like cooking, tailoring, blacksmithing, trading goods in a commerce, carpentry, etc. to different styles of combat like melee, magic, ninja, archery, puppetry, etc. all on 1 character. Although graphics and gameplay is still a bit dated, even after 14 years the game is still rich in content such as fashion contests, cooking contest, jousting, playing in or viewing large concerts, training pets, and so on and continues to be Nexon's most generous game.

threads.sub: /LFG/ - Small MMORPG looking for group general
threads.com:
Do you play an MMORPG (or private server) that is generally too small to level with other people either because everyone else is at level cap, group leveling is considered outdated, or because there is just not enough people to form groups for group content? Is there an MMORPG or private server that you would play if there were people to level with? Or maybe you're looking for a new MMORPG (or private server) to play with some people.

This is not a thread to find people to play popular MMORPGs with (Guild Wars 2, World of Warcraft or its more popular private servers, New World, Lost Ark, FFXIV, CoH Homecoming, Return of Reckoning, etc). This is for the dead, dying, or just very small MMORPGs (or at least the ones in which it is a struggle or impossible to find people for group content while leveling) such as EverQuest I and II, LotRO, DDO, Asheron's Call, Age of Conan, and small private servers. As ultimately I do not know which ones exactly are hard to find groups for, this is up to your discretion and is ultimately a thread guideline.

Only advertise here if you are serious about helping form a leveling group or even a community (such as a guild) on your game. Coordinate with people on times (if a group) or simply a server and faction/realm (if a guild/community).

One game I keep coming back to, for the past 15 years or so, is Urban Dead, a 10,000 square board game where survivors repair and barricade buildings, and zombies seek them out and try to break in and kill them. This is accomplished through a clever assortment of construction and destruction skills, communication abilities, metagaming, in-game coordination, and social connections. There are organized zombie groups, player-killer societies, people who hunt player killers, and various survivor groups focused on defending unique locations. All of this is done in a turn-based way where you earn a turn each half hour up to a total of 50, which you can spend all at once or spread out over the course of the day. This means you can travel long distances in a short time, or spend the day guarding and scouting in short sessions, but not both.

Urban Dead has one factor which I think is the most important for a multiplayer community - a relatively small and permanent player base which doesn't move between servers. Everyone in the game is always there unless they quit. Your character never logs out unless you stop playing for several days, so if somebody enters your stronghold and murders your leader - or you - or bad news comes over the radio, you learn about it when you return.

I am grossly oversimplifying all of this and also I am a little drunk, but at the end of the day what you have is frankly a fairly toxic game, but made up of many communities some of which aren't toxic, and it's the game in which I've made the most friends. I'm even friends with some of my in-game enemies, while I've come to hate some of the people working in my own faction.

Note that this is an old screenshot. Many of the survivors hubs are abandoned and there are only a few thousand active players left. You will need discord to find them, but once you find your niche you're going to know some really good people.

>>770593
There are a lot of things to despise about Diablo Immortal, but they have nailed it in terms of community. For a while I suspected that my good experience was the result of choosing a server called Deckard Cain - perhaps an older player base eager to represent for D2 - but after a merge with three other servers I was proven wrong. Immortal has the best community I've seen since the early days of Minecraft. It's deliberate and revolutionary, and I'm afraid we will lose it when the game fails, just as we lost countless good ideas when Asheron's Call and Anarchy Online failed.

To try and keep this as simple as possible:

The guilds on an Immoral server do some challenges to become Shadow, which is a sort of brotherhood of guilds who are in a constant cycle to overthrow the Immortals, a set of 3 allied guilds with special privileges. Each week, the Shadow guilds work to increase their power, then compete against each other for the right to challenge the Immortal guilds. The top ranking Shadows then fight the Immortals, and if they win a throwdown ensues to determine which Shadow guild will take the Immortal throne. When they do this, they pick two other guilds to join them.

What all this boils down to is regular competition between guilds who mostly need to work together, towards a showdown between factions whose members used to be allies and will be allies again soon. In half a year of playing, I have NEVER seen toxicity in chat beyond a short burst of infighting following the server merge. I am a terrible player with a gimped character, but I'm in one of the top guilds on my server, and have a raiding group that carries me. Before and after any contest you see nothing but gg and thanks in the public chat. I won't kid you, almost everything else about the game is either boring or just plain terrible, but it's my main game anyway because, socially, all the things we lost when WoW went to shit and the other MMOs failed, are here in this game, for now.

>>771357
Before/At player level 5 you can use a friend referral code for two heroes (Raynor, Sylvanas).
Completing the tutorial lets you pick a free hero (Tyrande, Jaina, Muradin).
You want to get to player level 25 to get 100 gems (premium currency) and then you can buy one hero bundle in the shop.
Player level is just the sum of all hero levels so play your lowest level heroes since they're the fastest to get levels with, when you get to level 5 with a hero you get 500 gold which is your main income combined with daily quests.
ARAM lets you pick from all heroes (even ones that aren't on rotation) so you can pick a level 1 hero there, a win will usually get that hero to level 2 if you really want to speedrun to player level 25 for the gems/bundle.

Don't re-roll loot boxes, save the gold for the heroes you want.

last_replies.com:
I'm in the same boat as these anons >>746009 >>756833 where I want a great faction war MMO, but there just aren't any good options on the market right now.

The best time I had playing MMOs was in Space Cowboy Online (aka ACE Online or Air Rivals). There was a PVE questline but it was just to level you up for PvP and to give you a little bit of flavor context as to what your nation is like and what you are fighting for. Once a month, the players of each nation would elect a nation leader who could set vendor taxes and distribute the nation's warchest and schedule when wars happened (usually on weekend afternoons). During war, you had hundreds of players pushing into enemy territory and capturing points, people flying ahead to scout out for enemy movements, people infiltrating deep into enemy territory trying to find a spot to hide in and start portalling in reinforcements. You had desperate battles at chokepoints and counter pushes. Eventually one side would reach the gates of the enemy city and there would be a climatic showdown to blow up their mothership. During week days, there were smaller wars over capturable airships and space stations, which functioned as guildhalls for whichever brigade claimed them. Sadly that game was killed off by the implementation of a literal P2W slotmachine that gave you the best armors in the game.

I am currently playing GW2. WvW is fun in small doses, but there is no flavor. You are not fighting for the Anti-Nationalists against the Imperialists or for the Horde against the Alliance. You're red team fighting against green and blue team, who are indistinguishable from you in aesthetics, and there is no lore. You don't feel like you are fighting in the name of your country. You can claim forts in the name of your guild, but you can't decorate the fort, and the keep gets taken back by the enemy within an hour anyway. Sadly WvW has been forgotten by the dev team and will never become more than what it is now.

last_replies.com:
As long as you can keep your autism in check, the Discovery Mod for Freelancer still has a server running and still gets updates. Entirely new factions, tons of new systems, ships, classes of ships, as well as locations and jump points in already existing systems, and a lot more. You can also start off as any faction instead of having to work your way into their favor like in the base game. Just check the "reset guide" on the wiki. They have a link to the base game on archive.org, and a download link for the mod on the same page.
Completely free, the only downside is the only existing server is 24/7 RP. So you are limited in a "role". You literally can't fly a ship or mount any equipment not supported by your role-specific ID card in-game item. You are also expected to RP like a ship pilot and not be OOC in chat. No randomly attacking people out of the blue, stuff like that. There's about 10 people on the server on average and 20 during peak hours, so you won't be expected to RP very often. and even less if you avoid popular areas like the Omega systems, Omicron systems, and Liberty systems.
It's nothing amazing, but it's pretty good for a heavily modded version of a game that came out in 2003.

https://wikiwiki.jp/rolonline/%E3%82%AF%E3%83%A9%E3%82%B9/1%E6%AC%A1%E3%82%AF%E3%83%A9%E3%82%B9#ENC

So, to explain the "usage" of a weapon on a class, we refer to the weapon type and then the amount of skills it can use, to the skills we refer to as "charges" because you have to hold down a button to charge the skills.
So for Cleric's Left Hand it's Hammer/Staff/Mace C3 and Cleric's Right Hand it's Mace C3 and Ring C4.
Ring basically means Magic.

For Enchanter it is Rapier/Staff C3, Mace C4, Bow C1 (which is really useless desu.) and for the Offhand it's Rapier/Mace C2 and Ring C3.

Running Enchanter also means you will always have a chance to attack enemy weakness elements and it enables your Weapons to have Magic Damage scaling.
Long-term i would recommend to start with Enchanter and take a Memoria for Heal I and run it as a shared class skill on your Enchanter, but running pure Cleric i guess gives you access to cheaper heals.
Since the way Memoria works, using Heal I on Enchanter will be a bit more expensive since it's not it's native skill.

threads.name: Anonymous
threads.com:
This is the only conclusion I've been able to come to.

Being in a world with thousands of players seem fun at first but that only works when you’re a kid. Truth is it’s really boring. Meeting a good variety of NPCs is way more fun than meeting players that act the same way as in real life depressed emo wannabe. It’s funny how a lot of MMORPG players seek the role playing aspect through PC simulations of Tabletop RPGs that only display still images and do not realize that they could do the same in the 3D world they’re used to reside in… to a certain extent, which brings up my second point.

You have no impact on the world. Whether you like it or not I’m going to use pic related as an example because if you’re on this website you’ve seen it. Let’s say you have a world like the Aincrad where you need to defeat a floor boss to access the next area. Even if you just killed that boss, everybody still have to do the same. You somehow didn’t pave the way for other players. So you’re in the same world, but not really. Whatever you do do not matter and cannot reach others. The reason for that is obvious; most people wouldn’t be able to play the game. Ironically, somewhat large scale co-op games are better than MMORPGs if you want to experience a virtual world with other people because they allow less restrictions on that matter.

When it comes to gameplay, I wonder why so many people start drooling whenever they see the number of players allowed in raids increase although 40 players raids like in Ashes of Creation feels nothing like cooperating. At this point you’re literally a needle in a haystack, it doesn’t feel like you’re fighting anything, you don’t need to pay attention to the game at all. You’re only here to meet the number requirements of some purely stats-based fake difficulty.

From wii.guide/wiimmfi:
>Wii (no homebrew)
1. Insert your game disc.
2. Go into your internet connection settings and set the DNS server of your console to 95.217.77.151.
3. Go to the WC24 contract information (third button after clicking on “Internet” in the settings).
4. Confirm that you do want to use WC24 and the shop channel
5. The Wiimmfi patcher page should show up. If it doesn’t, and you still see the default license agreement, your router might not be compatible with this method.
6. Wait for about 1 minute and 30 seconds for the patcher to load
The game should now start with the Wiimmfi patch included
>Nintendo DS
You'll need a Wi-Fi network with WEP or no security
1. Go in the Nintendo DS Wi-Fi settings. This can be accessed inside the game you want to play online with.
2. Set up a connection.
3. Type in 164.132.44.106 as the primary DNS.
4. Type in 1.1.1.1 as the secondary DNS (if it gives you problems, try 8.8.8.8).
5. Save your connection settings and perform a connection test. If it’s successful, then you’re ready to play.
